front.title: IETF Trust Changes to Accommodate IASA Restructuring

abstract.t: An ongoing change plans to replace the current IETF Administrative Oversight Committee (IAOC) with a board for a newly created administrative organisation. This change will have an impact in the IETF Trust as well, primarily because members of the IAOC have also served as trustees of the IETF Trust. This memo describes the dependencies between the Trust and the IETF administrative framework, and suggests changes to allow the IETF Trust to continue its service to the IETF and others, with minimal impact to those services.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The arrangements relating to administrative support for the IETF (referred to as the "IETF Administrative Support Activity" (IASA) ) are being changed.

One of the planned changes is to remove the IETF Administrative Oversight Committee (IAOC) and replace it with a board that oversees a new, formal organisation whose boundaries towards Internet Society (ISOC) and elsewhere are clearly defined.
However, the IAOC is interwtined with another IETF organisation, the IETF Trust (), and as a result, changes to IAOC will also impact the IETF Trust.

This memo describes the dependencies between the Trust and the IETF administrative framework, and suggests changes to allow the IETF Trust to continue its service to the IETF and others, with minimal impact to those services.

The rest of this document is organised as follows. describes briefly what the IETF Trust is and how the current organisation is arranged. points out the dependencies between IETF Trust and the rest of IASA, and how those dependencies require action in the context of IASA 2.0 project. discusses the general approach to these changes, i.e., minimal changes and keeping the IETF Trust as its own standalone entity. describes the specific changes that are needed, along with potential alternatives where they exist. Finally, discusses what needs to be done before these, final changes take effect.

section.title: Background
section.t: The purpose of the IETF Trust is to acquire, hold, maintain, and license certain existing and future intellectual property and other property used in connection with the administration of the IETF . The intellectual property is, for instance, rights that the IETF contributors grant for text in RFCs and Internet Drafts. The IETF Trust also manages trademarks and domains such as "IETF" and ietf.org. The IETF Trust is also serving the broader Internet community by holding domains and trademark associated with IANA .

The IETF Trust is a legal entity, registered in the Commonwealth of Virginia . The budget for IETF Trust is covered from the Internet Society and a few other sources. The main expenses relate to legal assistance and domain name and trademark registrations.

Currently, the members of the IAOC are also serving as trustees of the IETF Trust. The founding documents specify persons eligible to become trustees as having to be then-current members of the IAOC . The documents also specify that if for any reason there are fewer than three individuals serving as trustees, then the IESG, or the IESG's successor as the leadership of the IETF, shall appoint one or more individuals to serve in a temporary capacity as Trustee(s) until eligible persons can be found.

In the current system there are eight IAOC members. They are named by the IETF Nominations Committee or NomCom (two members), IESG (one member), IAB (one member), Internet Society Board of Trustees (one member), along with three ex-officio members via their roles as IETF Chair, Internet Society CEO, or IAB Chair.

section.title: Dependencies
section.t:
The following dependencies exist:
The IETF Trust depends on having IAOC members as Trustees. A new arrangement for this needs to be found.
The IETF Trust needs to allow organisations to use the trademarks and other assets its owns. As a new legal entity is created for IETF administration, it becomes necessary to authorize this new entity to use the assets that it needs.
In addition, for the part of IETF Trust funding coming directly from Internet Society today, that arrangement could either stay or be changed in some manner.

section.title: General Approach
section.t: There are two basic approaches to resolving the dependencies. One could imagine merging all IETF Trust functions in the new IASA structure and under the planned new legal entity. This memo advocates a second approach where the IETF Trust is kept independent, but its dependencies on, for instance, IAOC members are resolved through other means.

The rationale for advocating the second approach is in part to avoid causing too much change for the IETF Trust at a time when the IETF administrative structure is ongoing major change. And, perhaps more importantly, the IETF Trust and other administrative IETF process are quite different. While very important, the IETF Trust is a very low activity entity where changes, if any, are minimal and gradual. There are no pressing issues, and the organisation serves the broader Internet community than perhaps the day-to-day and more IETF meetings-focused other parts of IASA.

section.title: Specific Changes to IETF Trust
section.t: This memo also suggestes that the new IETF administrative entity be given rights to use the IETF domain names and trademarks, which seems reasonable given that the administrative entity is the one that administers the IETF web site anyway.

Secondly, if we want to keep the IETF Trust separate as discussed in , there needs to be a new way to name trustees. At the time the trustees served both the IETF Trust and the IAOC, many of the requirements for naming a particular group of people were driven by the IAOC's requirements. For the IETF Trust in the new model, some of those arrangements can be rethought, both in terms of the number and source of the trustees, as well as the desired qualifications and length of terms.

Several options are possible, of course. A newly designed naming process could be devised. This memo argues for relatively limited change, however, largely on the basis of the IETF Trust arrangements generally working well, and on the relatively modest expected time commitments combined with the need for very careful management of the assets.
As a result, this memo suggests that a smaller group of five trustees is sufficient, with three named by the Nomcom, one named by the IESG, and one named by the Internet Society Board of Trustees.

In addition, the terms for the Nomcom- and IESG-named trustees should be set to three years.
Note: It does not seem necessary for the IAB Chair or the Internet Society CEO to be members of the IETF Trust. Similarly, the IESG can choose the person they want to oversee the IETF Trust, and it is not necessary that this person be the IETF Chair. In general, the tasks of the IETF Trust are well defined, and while there is a need for coordination, it does not need to be at the level of chairs or CEOs.
The normal IETF rules regarding recalls and other Nomcom-related processes continue to apply .
The next section discusses what document changes are needed to make these changes.

Finally, this memo suggests that funding arrangements for the IETF Trust stay as they are, but for the part of IETF Trust funding that comes from Internet Society today be managed via the new administrative entity instead.
An alternative approach would be to make no changes.

section.title: Required Documentation Changes
section.t: This document, if approved, will revise the current procedures defined in and .

In addition, the Trust Founding Documents need to be revised to specify how trustees can become eligible in the new arrangement. Such a revision belongs to the IETF Trust, with community review before making a change.

The rights of the new IETF administrative entity with regards to IETF Trust copyright, trademarks, and domain names need to be formally acknowledged. This also an action that belongs to the IETF Trust.

section.title: Transition
section.t: The new entity for IETF administration is being set up, and at some point, the IAOC will also be discontinued. Fortunately, there's no pressing need to change all the components at the same time. As discussed above (), the IESG holds the ability to continue to name trustees. Once the changes suggested in are in place, the IETF Trust will have management nominated in the usual manner, and the exceptional IESG process is no longer needed.

However, the following actions do need to take place when a new administrative entity is created:
Any changes to how current Internet Society funding for IETF Trust need to be agreed. Perhaps this agreement can be a part of the operating agreement that is being drafted. And as discussed above, it seems logical that the IETF Trust funding will be arranged through the new administrative entity.
The new administrative entity needs to be given rights to use the IETF domain names and trademarks. This is normal IETF Trust business and can be handled in the usual manner.
